Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 4, 2024
Data:
More and more I've been finding myself surprised by TP-Link and their smart-home offerings. This is no different. The lightbulbs are exceptionally easy to get going and to pair. And they don't flash weird colors prior to setup like every other smart bulb I've used.

Unlike most other smart bulbs, I just shoved this thing, set it up in my app, and was on my way. This thing was detected by Amazon in my Alexa app almost immediately, and voice control was rather effortless (minus the typical quirks with voice control) for the most part.
Colors as well as different white modes were easy to select, very easy to tell apart color-wise, and rather vibrant. Not as vibrant as some other brands, but the ease of use and ability to use with Home Assistant without needing to flash firmware or mess with anything more advanced easily make up for that, in my opinion.
Did I mention that it works with Home Assistant? Kind of a huge buying point for me these days. Control seems to be local despite me needing to have an account. As of the time of me writing this review, I currently have these on a VLAN in my network, unable to speak out, and they still work flawlessly.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2024
Data:
Solid product. The colors are spot on. I especially like the different shades of white through the day if you set them to adjust with the time.
Tried other bulbs w Alexa and they either didn't work at all or had to be reconnected all the time. What a pain!
I definitely recommend these as smart bulbs for use with Alexa but...
The first several bulbs I purchased, I checked the box at checkout to link them to my Amazon/Alexa and bam! They setup immediately with Alexa. I didn't have to use the manufacturer's app.
However, I bought another set, checked the same box at checkout, and they did not connect using Alexa.
So I downloaded the manufacturer's app and set one up and it broke the connection with all the previous bulbs and Alexa. I couldn't even delete the original ones from the Alexa app.
So I...
-Disabled the skill from the manufacturer's app within Alexa
-Set up all the bulbs using the manufacturer's app
-Deleted the Alexa app from my phone and reinstalled it (don't worry, everything is still there once you log in)
-Re-enabled the skill in the Alexa app
All the lights showed up in the Alexa app again. Everything was good in the Alexa app as far as routines and everything else, except the lights. I had to re-add the lights to the existing routines.
So I would suggest setting up the bulbs in the manufacturer's app FIRST and enable the skill in the Alexa app.
I hope this is helpful :)

Date: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2024
Data:
The Kasa app for iPhone and Android works very well; getting used to never flicking the switch on the outlet is important; teaching older clients to not flick multiple times means a LOT as if you flick it on/off a set number of times in a row, it factory resets the device, something I'm not a huge fan of.
The integration with Alexa and Apple HomeKit is well done, and the integration with Android is far less so; one of the key components missing in the Google integration is that you're pretty bound to one user being able to use the voice to turn on/off devices, whereas on Alexa/Homekit, it is easy to have multiple users do so.
Color change options matter. There are some brightness settings, but even at full bright you are talking the equivalent of about a 45W LED, so don't have expectations of a bright bulb. The base of this bulb also runs hot in comparison to several non-smart LED, which I assume is to be expected; after purchasing more than 48 of these, this has been a constant so I can't say it is a "one-off" experience. Will it impact longevity? That's hard to say.
The wifi range of these devices is spectacular for what they are; in fact, I've managed full functionality on these devices via wifi where signal is not available for laptops/etc. Really impressed by whatever they are doing there.
In comparison to competitor products, I ended up using TP-Links because of cost and general implementation. I do wish they would tie reset to a button press/etc. on the bulb itself instead of "flick your light switch 3 times fast" which is too easy for an installed bulb to be accidentally reset after you equip a smart home. With that being my only real complaint, I'd recommend.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 30, 2024
Data:
I have at least 26 Kasa/TP Link Devices and didn't have any problems until I ordered 8 bulbs and 4 plugs on a good sale in September 2023. My plan was to replace older bulbs from a different company so I only have one app to setup all my devices. I have only thrown away one out of four of the bulbs from the other company and I have had them all
The bulbs worked fine until January when they started to fail one by one in different ways. Of course, this was too long to get them replaced through Amazon. I now have 6 of 8 bulbs malfunctioning. After troubleshooting and trying to fix each one for a couple months I contacted support. Two different times they told me to try things I already had. I guess I finally said the magic words of "replace them under warranty" and we started the RMA process. Their warranty says they can also replace the bulbs with refurbished ones even if yours are practically new.
Here's where it gets strange. Somehow I ended up with some KL 130 bulbs even though I ordered KL 125. I assume that either Amazon sent me the wrong box OR someone had some messed up bulbs, ordered the KL 125 and switched them out with their broken KL 130. There's no way to know. Regardless, I somehow have these malfunctioning bulbs that Kasa will not replace because I don't have a proof of purchase or serial number for the bulbs. Kasa doesn't print the serial numbers on the bulbs themselves and I never dreamed I would need to keep the boxes given how many devices I own from this company. I even told them several times that the only colored bulbs I own from them were the two receipts I provided and it's not enough for them to stand by their product.
These products were also registered in the kasa app the day I got them, but they needed to be added to a different website to fix them via warranty. The process says I will choose shipping method but I haven't made it that far in the process yet. I will update whenever I get there.
The main reason I bought these bulbs was to use them in conjunction with wall switches; mainly, if someone forgot to turn out the lights and I saw them on from a different room I could still turn them off. I also use them in rooms where the furniture is far away from the light switch (such as a bedroom) so that I can turn off the lights without getting up. However, if the power goes out the lights will come on even though I have them set to remember their last state. I assume this means that the data for this setting is stored in the cloud and not in the hardware of the device. More than once I have been awakened because a power flicker turns the lights on while I'm sleeping and I either have to get up and turn them off at the switch or wait for the modem and router to connect to the internet so I can turn them off.
Also, these lights don't have customization effects like the light strips do. I can't set up a thunderstorm effect in a whole room; the effect will only work on the strips.
TL;DR: If they send you different bulbs than what you ordered you're screwed when they malfunction. Serial numbers aren't printed on the bulbs. All bulbs come on during a power flicker regardless of your setting. They don't allow you to use effects like Kasa's light strips do.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on March 24, 2024
Data:
The Kasa Smart Light Bulbs offer a convenient and customizable lighting solution with their full color-changing and dimmable features, compatible with Alexa and Google Home. However, while they have their merits, their reliability in staying connected to the internet leaves something to be desired.
On the positive side, these bulbs provide a wide range of colors and brightness levels, allowing for personalized lighting to suit any mood or occasion. The integration with popular smart home assistants like Alexa and Google Home adds to their versatility, enabling convenient voice control for seamless operation.
That said, the inconsistency in maintaining a stable internet connection can be frustrating and impacts their overall usability. There are occasions when the bulbs fail to connect or become disconnected from the network, disrupting the intended lighting settings and requiring manual intervention to reestablish connectivity. Often just one will disconnect, meaning I can’t control them both at the same time. Other times, both disconnect.
While the lack of a required hub simplifies the setup process, it seems that the reliance solely on a 2.4GHz Wi-Fi network may contribute to the connectivity issues experienced by some users. It's worth noting that in environments with multiple smart devices or interference, these issues may be exacerbated.
In conclusion, the Kasa Smart Light Bulbs offer a decent lighting solution with their color-changing and dimmable capabilities, enhanced by compatibility with popular smart home platforms. However, the inconsistency in internet connectivity detracts from their overall reliability and usability. For users seeking a seamless smart lighting experience, it may be worth exploring alternative options with more robust connectivity features.

Data:
I purchased these bulbs to get my entire house on one system as previously we were using a hodgepodge of wifi bulbs my husband and I had each acquired before we met. So, there was nothing wrong with the bulbs I was previously using, I was just looking for something cohesive, which I think is relevant to my review.
I will say, setting up the bulbs is very easy, easier than other bulbs I have used. However, I quickly ran into several issues that are more annoyances than anything else:
1. The same brightness/color settings on two different bulbs do not look the same. I have 2 matching lamps in my living room and when I chose the same brightness and color for each, they looked totally different. One was yellow and one was white. I couldn’t get them to look the same no matter what I did. This is extremely frustrating - as the same product, they should look the same. If you do not have 2 lamps in the same room that need to match, this probably won’t be an issue for you. I played around with all the bulbs in the package and finally found 2 that matched when set to the same settings.
2. One of my bulbs lags so slowly behind the app. When I turn it on it is ok, but when I click off it takes often ~2 minutes to shut off. This is frustrating because you never know if it will work or not, and if you click off again (because the app is slow), it finally catches up and clicks on and off several times. However, I plan to use these on a timer 99% of the time so this isn’t a huge issue at this moment.
3. As above, app is very slow.
4. Groups cannot have a set schedule - so what is the point of groups? I finally figured out the non-matching bulb colors, and realized I could group the two bulbs in the same room together to have one control. Awesome! I deleted the schedule from each individual bulb and went to create the schedule for the group…except you cannot create a schedule for a group. Huge flaw on Kasa’s part. Again, I only plan on using the bulbs on a schedule so I can set each bulb to the same schedule individually. Not that big of a deal at this time, but still annoying. What is the point of a group without a group schedule? I would also like to note that the lagging bulb mentioned above lags even when you click on/off for the group.
5. The mentioned bulb that lags behind the rest was having an issue where it would never turn back on to the last setting, it would always turn on to some random setting I never used. I want to say maybe this is a defective bulb. However, it now perfectly matches its counterpart in the same room whereas the bulb I previously tried to match it with does not match. So, are they all defective? I may never know.
I will say I uninstalled/reinstalled this bulb in the app and while it still lags behind the others, it now turns on to the last setting as it should.
Overall, I do like the range of colors and brightness on these bulbs and will stick with them because Kasa has a wide range of products I may want to add to my home in the future. I have found workarounds for the issues mentioned here. However, I definitely expected more out of this product.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2023
Data:
Bright Idea or Dim Disappointment?
Pros:
1. **Easy-Breezy Setup:** Setting up the Kasa Smart Bulb was smoother than butter on a hot biscuit. It practically installed itself, making me feel like a tech wizard without the hassle of incantations and spellbooks.
2. **Technicolor Dream Light:** This bulb isn't your average Joe. It boasts a whole spectrum of colors, turning your room into a disco, a tropical paradise, or a cozy cave—all at the command of your fingertips. It's like having a mood ring for your living space.
3. **Lazy-Person Approved:** The ability to control this bulb with your voice is the epitome of laziness achievement unlocked. I can now command my lights without lifting a finger, literally. "Hey, Kasa, make it cozy," and boom, I'm bathed in warm, ambient light.
Cons:
1. **App-ocalypse:** While the app works, it feels like it's auditioning for a role in a horror movie—slow, clunky, and occasionally possessed. Trying to change settings can be as frustrating as getting that last drop of ketchup out of the bottle.
2. **Dim as a Teenager's Mood:** The brightness of this bulb can be a bit underwhelming. It's like trying to read a map by firefly light. If you're looking to illuminate the room like the surface of the sun, you might need more than one of these bulbs.
3. **Wi-Fi Dependency:** This bulb depends on Wi-Fi like I depend on caffeine. If your Wi-Fi goes on strike, so does your smart lighting dream. It's like having a high-tech lantern during a power outage—looks cool until you realize it's just a fancy paperweight.
In the grand scheme of illuminating decisions, the Kasa Smart Bulb walks the tightrope between convenience and occasional frustrations. If you can overlook the app quirks and the fact that it won't blind you with its brilliance, it's a nifty addition to your smart home arsenal. Just don't expect it to solve world peace or fold your laundry.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2023
Data:
Title says all. Added the bulbs to my Wi-Fi network via the TP Link Kasa app, installed TP Link Kasa integration into Home Assistant and after a few minutes the bulbs were detected no problem. After that you are off to the races! Use Home Assistant to configure the bulbs to power on with automations/timers, or use the Kasa software.. your choice.
Been using for a couple of weeks and no major issues thus far. The real bummer is that after a power outage, when the power returns the Kasa light bulbs turn back on… even if the bulbs had been OFF before the power went off. I looked in TP Link forums and other folks have complained about this too. It is a known issue that will probably never be fixed (TP Link doesn’t have the best software update reputation). To work around this I applied a preset of “1% brightness” for the power-on state. That way if power goes out and comes back on, the bulbs are only on at 1% and don’t waste as much electricity.
Power outages are rare, so this is a minor annoyance. The software seems to have a setting to account for this, but the setting isn’t fully built out. Not sure why TP Link never finished that option. I guess another workaround could be to hook the lamps with the bulbs up to a UPS, but that seems like overkill for this!
Other than that the bulbs work great and the colors are awesome. I wish I could use these bulbs in “fully enclosed luminaries” but I cannot. I didn’t realize that until AFTER purchase. But it seems there is no LED smart bulb that can be used in a fully enclosed luminary. I intended to install these in fully enclosed ceiling lights, but after reading that warning decided to place them in some reading lamps instead.

Data:
Update - After fighting with the Kasa app quite a bit, I was finally able to get it to work (had to reset password multiple times to get it to send a confirmation email that actually worked).
The light does what it says - allows color choices, works with Alexa, etc.
2 downsides:
* The small downside - only 2.4 Ghz WiFi compatibility. This could cause problems with some newer home routers. My ancient (by tech standards) ASUS RTN66U has been a shockingly reliable workhorse for many years so this one is no big deal to me.
* The bulb gets hot. Really hot. The base of the bulb, where all the electronics are was scalding hot after 10 minutes of being on. This was in a downward facing glass light fixture -- no heat could escape vertically. When I later put the bulb in torchiere lamp where the top is totally open, it did not have the same heating problem. BUT, that heat is still being produced. It's just escaping up away from the bulb. I would never put this bulb somewhere enclosed and I assume that so much heat production is a significant waste of electricity compared to a normal LED bulb. I had never really considered this factor before - received this light free with an Alexa Echo Pop. After thinking about it I'd bet that most smart bulbs (and smart devices in general) have this same basic problem. They do more stuff; they must consume more power to do it; not sure I'm in favor of that trend.
ORIGINAL Review: Junk so far
1) Requires use of the Kasa app which pretty much gives the developer rights to everything on my phone. Not excited about that.
2) Grudgingly, I downloaded the app. When creating an account from the app, I receive a success message yet cannot log in. I tried creating an account from their website. Also says successful but I cannot log in either on app on site.
Will give it another try in a bit - maybe there servers are having problems - but, after that, will consider it a waste of my time.

Data:
To start, this type of product is one I would recommend buying new vs used via a Warehouse Deals deal. The first used set I bought had only two of the four operable, perhaps because the two that didn’t fully work were tied to someone else’s account - gave me a “cloud error”. The second set someone had swapped non-smart bulbs into the Kasa box and returned those. So for just a couple bucks more, you can get ones that haven’t been messed with.
The new ones I received set up quickly and without issue.
It’s nice to be able to set color temperature, but I’d prefer to be able to enter the number directly as a number in K versus trying to fine tune with a slider bar where it’s hard to get to an exact value without over or undershooting. Also, the option to automatically set the color temp and brightness level based in time of day doesn’t always work as expected, sometimes being whiter than it should be when it’s later in the evening.
I do have it connected to Alexa and can use voice commands to turn lights on and off, but it can be a little laggy and somewhere there should be a list of allowable commands. I tried to ask Alexa to change the color temperature to 3000K, but it couldn’t do that.
So these fundamentally work, but the operation could still be more intuitive and the UI of the app could be improved.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2024
Data:
I have a lot of Kasa products in my house, I recently completed a project with various models of Wifi light switches (rewiring each from standard flip-style light switches), and have really enjoyed having my house automated and Alexa-aware. I added these light bulbs so that our night table and back porch would have some personality with different color choices. I was hopeful and excited to get a 4-pack of the 800 Lumens bulbs.
The bulbs were easy to connect, and I haven't had any problems with connectivity, they work well-WHEN THEY WORK. Alexa turns them on and off, dims them and changes the color. However, so far I have had 2 out of the 4 pack fail, and I mean fail DEAD. There is a reset process you do by turning on and off the light bulb a certain number of times at certain intervals (on-off-on in 1 second intervals), but that doesn't do anything. The bulb is dead in another working lamp (the bulb in a different lamp works fine in the one where the bad bulb failed). We have had no power outages or blinks/brownouts/etc. The bulb is just dead.
In addition to the failed bulb, I expected TPLink support to be more responsive. Support was a disappointment. You have to register the bulbs with the SN (serial number?) on the box, so DO NOT THROW THE BOX AWAY. Support will want a receipt, and a photo of the box's SN. WHO KEEPS A BOX?!?! The communication exchange with tech support both times has taken several days minimum, by the time you answer the basic questions they have, then they send you an RMA link (the second time, I tried to tell them the answers to the questions ahead of time-they don't read/listen to your email comments). When they approve the RMA, YOU HAVE TO PAY FOR THE REPLACEMENT BULB *AND* THE SHIPPING. Then, if they receive the bad bulb back, they refund you the cost of the replacement bulb.
Honestly, I'm considering other manufacturers for colored bulbs, based on the poor level of tech/RMA support. I have other TPLink Kasa products that work just fine, including network switches, light switches, plugs, etc. But my advice is to stay away from these bulbs.

Data:
This lightbulb explicitly forbids connections to open/unsecured WiFi networks (that is, without a password).
As many, I do not have control over the network configuration of the place I want to set this up in, which is a pretty common situation. In my case, the University I'm in does. It offers eduroam with certificate authentication or a MAC-address-whitelist-only but otherwise unsecured network for IoT devices that don't support that protocol. Data:
This light bulb is a complete disappointment. All smart features require the phone usage and physical switch ON. For example:
- schedules doesn't work if the light is off by a switch. Schedules do not pick up the intended bulb state if it was off. Forget about "lower light on sunset". If the schedule has been triggered while the bulb was off, it won't pick it up.
- after hard switch off, bulb could restore it's "state" (fixed setting) or "Circadian" mode. But it doesn't recall the off value. So, expect the bulb to blow your eyes in the middle of the night for about a minute, while it picks up the correct setting, and lower the brightness based on current time
- the bulb settings could not be changed while it is off, so you can't make a change in advance
The list goes on..
Essentially, it is a dumb bulb which you can control using your phone. Not suitable for bathrooms, and any other places, where you have a power switch.
Would not recommend buying it, the makers probably never used it.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2023
Data:
I really wanted to like these bulbs (1000 lumen). The price was right and my experience with the Kasa line of smart plugs has been very positive. I didn't need anything fancy, just some simple color-changing / adjustable white lights. And technically speaking, they meet that goal. You can change the colors and you can adjust the white temperature.
But there are problems.
First, the color: yes, you can adjust the color. Instead of tapping a name like "blue" or being able to enter an RGB value, you tap your desired color on a full-spectrum color wheel. This gives you a wide range of colors but makes it very difficult to select a basic color like "blue" or "red". And it makes it impossible to synchronize multiple lights to the same color. If you want to turn an entire room red, for example, each bulb will be a slightly different shade of red because you're not going to tap the exact same spot on the wheel four times. It's impossible. Kasa does have presets, but since each bulb gets its own presets, you can't use this to synchronize colors either.
Second, the white temperature has a similar problem. You can adjust using a slider that goes between 2700 and 9000K. But since the slider only takes up about a third of your screen, getting any kind of precision is almost impossible. If you want a specific temperature setting, like 3000K, you're either going to have to accept somewhere between 2900K - 3100K or spend 15 minutes trying to randomly land on 3000K exactly. Again, this isn't really a huge deal for a single lamp, but if you want to use multiple bulbs in a room somewhere (like using these for your main living room lighting), you're going to get multiple shades of white. This looks awful.
Third, the app is glitchy. Sometimes it just backs out of a bulb configuration screen. That's a lot of fun when you've finally almost got the exact color or temperature you want dialed in and it suddenly cancels your selection.
Fourth, network connectivity is just bad. All of my bulbs are within 30 feet of the wifi AP, and half of them are direct line of sight with no obstruction whatsoever. All of them randomly fail to connect. No rhyme or reason, they simply decide they won't do what the app tells them to do.
There are some good sides. This is the first smart bulb I've encountered that actually cranks out 1000 lumens (about as bright as an 11W LED, or slightly brighter than an old 60W incandescent). Unlike many cheap smart bulbs, these have no annoying whine or flicker. The Kasa app can be good; it works great with my smart plugs.
But there are just too many faults to recommend these. I'd say either go with a more established brand, or wait for TP-Link to fix all the faults.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2021
Data:
I have been using Kasa "smart" bulbs for some years now. Their older models (such as the white LB120) are absolutely great. I have some of those still in my apartment and they work perfectly. These newer models (color KL125) work alright except for the annoying fact that they disconnect from Wi-Fi randomly, especially when the light is turned off but the bulb still powered on (the light switch is on, but the bulb's light is off) . Seriously. Every single one of the four bulbs in this pack disconnects overnight, yet none of the older LB120 ones do. It's not my router, either: they're connected to a TP-Link router, after all.
These disconnects don't render the bulbs useless, but they're certainly not "smart" enough: to reconnect them, you have to flip their switch off and on again, which is not a terrible inconvenience, but it does sort of defeat the purpose of having smart bulbs in the first place.
I've also noticed these newer models don't always respond correctly to Alexa commands. For example, you'll ask for a color and Alexa will sometimes turn them white. I have an older color Kasa bulb as well (KL130) which also randomly disconnects (though not every day), but that one at least seems to always respond correctly to Alexa commands.
In short, Kasa bulbs started off great some years ago. The no-hub bulb was and is still an especially attractive feature, and they worked great some years ago. Today, however, it seems Kasa bulbs' quality has seriously deteriorated to the point where not even the no-hub feature can compensate for it.
I won't be returning these simply because it's too much of a hassle to dismount every single one of them again, pack them up, and ship them and then having to once again reconfigure my whole Kasa set-up. Also, like I said earlier, the bulbs are not exactly useless, just not "smart" enough. But I will be considering migrating from Kasa to some other system, unless TP-Link ships some firmware that fixes these issues.

Date: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2022
Data:
These are pretty decent bulbs, at least when they're on sale.
SETUP: Connecting the bulbs to wifi for the first time takes a little bit of fussing around and having the phone almost right next to the bulb during setup, after that it's smooth sailing. If you have the bulbs connected to separate network than your phone and other equipment (since it only supports 2.4 GHz), then the app will seamlessly switch your phone to the network the bulbs are on during app use and back to your original network when you're finished, which I appreciate.
These bulbs do NOT support bluetooth, zigbee, or 5GHz connections, so look elsewhere if any of that is a dealbreaker for you.
CUSTOMIZATION: This is where the price point of these bulbs starts to become apparent (in a bad way). The Kasa Smart app leaves quite a bit to be desired in comparison to Hue. The major pain point for me being that bulbs can't be synchronized with each other - meaning if you want them all to be a very specific shade of vivid sky blue, expect each bulb to be ever so slightly off enough to drive your OCD up a wall unless you're willing to fuss with it for a long time.
Each bulb can save up to 4 preset favorite colors but there's no way to share or synchronize those between bulbs; and with no way to enter a specific RGB or Hex code, so you'll be stuck fiddling with trying to match each bulb exactly on the color wheel.
Scenes work okay but configuration is a little tedious in comparison to Hue, as you have to manually add and configure each bulb to each scene.
Colors seem to misbehave at low brightness levels (less than 10%) and will either dull to an off-white or change to the nearest primary color.
Pretty much all of my issues could be fixed with software and firmware updates, but they're serviceable for the price - at least while on sale in my opinion. Until then, it doesn't seem like anything is going to dethrone Philips Hue.

I recently purchased the Kasa Smart Wifi Light Bulb 4-pack and I am somehow satisfied with my purchase. Here is why: the bulbs were easy to set up and connect to my wifi network. I love being able to control the lights with my phone or voice commands using Google Assistant. The multicolor feature is also a huge plus, it adds a fun element to my home and it also allows me to set different scenes or ambiance depending on the occasion. However, here are some pros and cons for getting Kasa Light Bulbs..
- These lightbulbs are very reasonably priced.
- The Kasa Smart ecosystem and accompanying app are excellent for controlling the bulbs.
- The installation process is easy and straightforward, thanks to the well-designed walkthrough instructions.
- The multi-color options are a great feature, adding more versatility and fun to your lighting.

- I recently noticed that the base of the lightbulb becomes quite warm after being in use for an hour. I am not sure if this will cause any problems, I will have to wait and see.
- One drawback of these bulbs is that they do not have Bluetooth or the ability to synchronize with music like some other options on the market.
- The process of setting up scenes and scheduling them to switch colors at certain events ( like sunrise / sunsets ) can be a bit complex.
FINAL THOUGHTS:
My thoughts on this hardware are mixed. On one hand, they are relatively inexpensive and they do function as intended. On the other hand, the issue with them getting warm and the limited functionality compared to other options make me hesitant to keep them. I am currently considering whether to keep them or return them.

So I wouldn't recommend these... unless it's in an area you don't mind the light being on after a power outage and wonder if the smart switches have the same issues.

I used to use bulbs manufactured by a company called LIFX. The problem with those bulbs were they constantly lost connectivity and could not be controlled from the app. I checked, did research

If you compare these to LIFX bulbs, allow me to detail some comparative facts:
Kasa bulb are not as brigh as LIFX bulbs but are less expensive,
The KASA app is easier to use than the LIFX app which sometimes gets confusing,
KASA bulbs are less expensive than LIFX bulbs.
When I used the LIFX bulbs, I found setup of the KASA bulbs was more user friendly.
The main difference between KASA and LIFX is the all important wi-fi connectivity. LIFX bulbs were constantly dropping their connections whereas the KASA bulbs have never dropped a wi-fi connection whereas the LIFX bulbs constantly needed a reboot to join them back to my network.
Finally, I’ve found that the KASA bulbs are more sensitive, (in a good way !) I placed LIFX bulbs in high hats, or recessed lights, whatever you call them, and they were unable to receive any signal, I have placed the KASA bulbs in recessed lights and find they work perfectly.
So there you have information on both manufacturers bulbs. Whichever you choose now is up to you, but I wanted to discuss the differences before making an educated decision.

Data:
There are SO many smart bulbs on the market these days, there are literally multiple youtube channels only about smart bulbs. Unfortunately, a lot of these bulbs are pretty pricey. My house is average size, and has over 40 lightbulbs in it. The cost can add up pretty quickly! I was pleased to find these Kasa bulbs for about $8 per bulb. It's a really good value for what you get.
These bulbs have 2 main advantages: (1) no hub is required. Many smart lighting systems require you to purchase a central hub that controls everything. Kasa's bulbs are independent devices that communicate over wifi and no hub is required. (2) Alexa compatibility. It's nice to incorporate setting lights an Alexa routine or control them on-demand via voice command. These bulbs offer a number of other advantages but these two are the biggest in my opinion.
However, the great price does come with a couple drawbacks. (1) low brightness. These are only 800 lumens. In areas with only one lightbulb, such as a windowless interior hallway, this can be pretty dim. (2) no animations. A lot of smart bulbs have settings that can flash the light in different colors and patterns. Even some of Kasa's other lights do this. But these bulbs do not. I hope this feature comes in a future software update.
So far, I have bought 12 of these bulbs, which covers the hallway, living room, and dining room. If I buy more smart bulbs I will probably buy more of the same to keep things consistent.

We also like the ability to turn on the outside lights from anywhere at any time. Sometimes if we are traveling, we get a movement notification from our Eufy cameras. If it's a person and not deer (the most common), I just turn on the outside lights to max white with the iPhone app.
I am curious as bug season starts if setting them to yellow during the evening will reduce the number of flying critters. Guess we'll find out soon!

I bought these programmable smart bulbs so that I could have lights turn on and off while I was away on trips. I have one that lights up my front porch every night, programmed to be on from dusk to dawn while the other three are in lamps around the house. They were very easy to set up (unlike the brand I got at Costco that could only use 2G wi-fi and just would not connect).
For these Kasa smart bulbs, you do need wi-fi and to download the software onto a smartphone. (I don't know if there are other options since I didn't use them.) They also connected to my Alexa but I like the Kasa app better. I can program each bulb to turn on and off at different times each day - a nice feature to make it seem like someone's home when they're not. I can also check if the lights are on or off while I'm away and make adjustments if necessary via the app.
I particularly liked that I could change the color of the bulbs. I'm not using solid colors like red or green but instead getting the perfect warm white for each room. I also like that I can adjust the brightness of the bulbs and the app lets me know how much I'm saving when dimmed to, for instance, 60% instead of 100% brightness.
I also use the Kasa plugs with my Alexa to turn on and off appliances like a fan I like to sleep with when it's hot but that Alexa will turn off an hour after I'm asleep. I highly recommend smart devices like these for elderly or disabled people who have ambulatory problems.
I've been using the Kasa smart plugs and smart bulbs every day since July 2021 and they've worked perfectly the whole time.
